comments.body:
```suggestion
- `MakeRootDataFrame` now constructs more reliable RDataFrames. It used to return RDFs with limited functionality.
```
I like my stronger wording better sorry :smile: If people were using `MakeRootDataFrame` in their code, they should be scared.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +199,203 @@- An exception is now thrown in case the size of ROOT's thread-pool changes between RDataFrame construction time and the time the event loop begins.
- Just-in-time compilation of large portions of the computation graph has been optimized, and it is now much faster. Please report any regressions you might encounter on [our issue tracker](https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/projects/ROOT).
- `MakeRootDataFrame` is now a safe way to construct RDFs. It used to return RDFs with more limited functionality.

comments.body: Do we have this option already in 6.22?

Hehe I was expecting this comment :smile: 

No, we don't have the option at the moment, but we will before we release: `pyroot_experimental` needs to disappear and we need to provide another option to build the old PyROOT. The name (`pyroot_legacy`) is a suggestion from my side, but if you have any other proposal let me know.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +291,295 @@
In 6.22, the new (experimental) PyROOT is built by default. In order to build with the old PyROOT instead, the option
`-Dpyroot_legacy=ON` can be used.

This new PyROOT also introduces the possibility of building its libraries for both Python2 and Python3 in a single

comments.body: should we mention ```PythonX_EXECUTABLE``` as well as a hint to CMake?
We could, yes, could you quickly try it and let me know whether it works?
yes it's what I do every time when I need to point to a specific Python installation

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +304,308 @@
If the user wants to build PyROOT for both Python2 and Python3, but not necessarily with the highest versions that
are available on the system, they can provide hints to CMake by using `-DPython2_ROOT_DIR=python2_dir` and/or
`-DPython3_ROOT_DIR=python3_dir` to point to the root directory of some desired Python installation. Similarly,
`Python2_EXECUTABLE` and/or `Python3_EXECUTABLE` can be used to point to particular Python executables.
